text: 2 The client is experiencing issues with custom widgets turning into 'Missing widget' entries after saving a page in SiteOrigin Page Builder, following updates to WPML v4.8.4 and String Translation v3.4.1. Additionally, there is a 404 error on the pagination of a custom post type archive, which temporarily resolves upon re-saving the ACF custom post type but reappears later.
solution: We have determined that the issue with the widgets is not directly caused by WPML or String Translation, but rather by how the custom widgets are loaded and registered. Ensure that all custom widgets are registered using the standard widgets_init action and confirm that widget IDs and class names exactly match those saved in SiteOrigin. Also, check for PHP 8.3 compatibility as the plugin might use outdated code. For the 'Missing widget' issue, disabling the 'Automatically detect best options for translating image texts' setting under WPML → Settings → Media Translation might resolve the issue. This is because WPML's media duplication process could be stripping necessary backslashes from the widget's data when saved in a secondary language. If problems persist, it's recommended to use wp_slash() when saving data to ensure backslashes are preserved. If these solutions do not resolve the issues or if new problems arise, we recommend opening a new support ticket. Additionally, it's advisable to check related known issues at https://wpml.org/known-issues/ , verify the version of the permanent fix, and confirm that you have installed the latest versions of themes and plugins. For further assistance, please visit our support forum at WPML Support Forum .

text: different sticky posts in different langauges The client is experiencing issues with managing sticky posts in different languages using WPML and another plugin to enable sticky post behavior for custom post types. Despite disabling 'Synchronize sticky flag' in WPML, the query still returns translations of sticky posts that are not selected as sticky in the current language.
solution:
We recommend filtering the sticky post IDs to include only those in the current language before running the query. Here is a step-by-step approach: $current_lang = apply_filters( 'wpml_current_language', null );
$stickies = array_filter(
get_option( 'sticky_posts', [] ),
fn( $id ) => apply_filters( 'wpml_post_language_details', null, $id )['language_code'] === $current_lang
);

$args = [
'post_type' => ['post', 'events'],
'post__in' => $stickies ?: [0],
'suppress_filters' => false,
];

$query = new WP_Query( $args );
This solution ensures that only sticky posts from the active language are queried, working regardless of fallback settings and without needing to change the post type translation mode.

text: There is an issue with the endpoint slugs of order-received in Woocommerce The client is experiencing an issue where the WooCommerce 'order-received' page only displays correctly in the default language. In other languages, it shows a single sentence instead of the translated thank you page.
solution: We have resolved this issue, and it will be included in the upcoming WCML v5.5.3.1 release. We recommend updating all WPML plugins once the update is available to ensure that the 'order-received' endpoint functions correctly in all languages. Before proceeding with the update, please ensure to take a full site backup.

text: After updating the site, the contact form stopped working, and the English version of the contact page displayed Swedish content. Additionally, a 503 Service Unavailable error appeared, suggesting a server-related issue.
solution: First, we recommend checking if the contact form works when temporarily deactivating the WPML plugins. If the issue persists, it might be related to caching or a security plugin blocking the request. Furthermore, ensure you are using the WPML Multilingual for CF7 plugin to maintain compatibility between WPML and Contact Form 7. You can find more information and installation instructions here: Using Contact Form 7 with WPML . Always back up your database before making any changes.

text: 1 The client wants to clone an existing site and then remove all languages except for one from the cloned site. They encountered issues after deactivating and deleting the WPML plugin, including errors during deletion, issues with the shop page not loading, incorrect main menu items, and needing to reset the homepage and shop page settings.
solution: We recommend the following steps to address the issues encountered: 1. Before starting to delete content after changing the source language, navigate to WPML → Settings and ensure to uncheck the options: - When deleting a post, delete translations as well - When deleting a taxonomy (category, tag, or custom), delete translations as well These settings prevent the deletion of translations when the main content is deleted, which can help avoid some of the issues experienced.

text: You are experiencing issues with product translations on your WooCommerce site using WPML, specifically with incorrect settings for the product_type field and non-equivalent products in different languages.
solution: First, ensure that the product_type and product_visibility fields are set to 'Not translatable' in WPML → Settings. This adjustment prevents these fields from being incorrectly translated. Next, to make all products visible, disable the 'Hide out of stock items from the catalog' option in WooCommerce → Settings → Products → Inventory.

text: 2 After migrating a development site to production, the client encountered an error message stating 'Site Moved or Copied - Action Required.' This occurred because the WPML plugin was not properly migrated using WPML's migration feature.
solution: We checked the site and confirmed there were no critical errors. The error banner was due to an outdated version of WPML from before version 4.4, which was not compatible with the newer 4.8.2 version. To resolve this, we: 1. Installed the last 4.4.X version of WPML along with the latest version of the Translation Management plugin. 2. Ran the "move" option in the WPML settings. 3. Updated WPML to the latest version to ensure compatibility and prevent similar issues. We recommend following these steps for updating WPML in the future to avoid version compatibility issues: https://wpml.org/faq/updating-wpml-manually/

text: 2 The client reported that the 'My Account' page was not translating properly into Dutch and Spanish, remaining in English despite other pages being correctly translated. Additionally, various WooCommerce interface strings on Dutch shop and category pages were not translating, and a specific MailPoet checkbox text on the checkout page was not displaying its Dutch translation.
solution: We identified that the issue was due to hardcoded links in the HTML that did not include the necessary language prefix after the default site language was changed. These links needed manual correction. For the 'Add to Wishlist' string, it was incorrectly set as Dutch in WPML, and we changed its source language to English before translating it to Dutch. Regarding the MailPoet checkbox text, it was determined that MailPoet is not fully compatible with WPML, which was causing the translation issue. We recommended checking for alternative solutions or methods for this specific string.

text: Translation is not shown correct After updating WPML, unexpected paragraph breaks appeared in the translated version of a page, while the original language displayed correctly.
solution: First, ensure you have the latest WPML version by navigating to Plugins -> Add new -> Commercial and clicking the Check for Updates button. You should update to WPML 4.8.3 if not already done. Next, update the original page and resend it for translation. You might need to cancel or delete the previous translation job. This process resolved similar issues in our tests.

text: You are trying to display untranslated products on the English version of your site using WPML, but the widget attribute filter does not work for displaying these products in the secondary language.
solution: This issue may occur because translated attributes are not associated with products in the secondary language that are not translated. This can lead to empty filter counts or the filter not appearing at all. We recommend duplicating the products into the secondary language or removing the attribute translations.

text: The client is developing a site for multiple countries in Europe and the Middle East and is considering using WPML for a multicountry and multilingual setup. They asked if they could create a multicountry site with custom languages like /en-fr for English France and /fr-fr for French France, enable auto-translate for all languages, understand how auto-translate works, and the best SEO strategy for multicountry and multilingual setups.
solution: We explained that language codes are based on the ISO standard, which is language-based, not region or country-based. For example, 'en' stands for English and 'fr' for French, while 'en-US' and 'en-GB' represent American and British English, respectively. Custom codes like 'en-FR' (English as spoken in France) do not exist in standard usage and would not be recognized by browsers or search engines. Therefore, using such codes would be ineffective. For geotargeting, which is different from language settings, we recommended using WPML in conjunction with a geotargeting plugin. This setup allows the site to display languages based on the visitor's IP location. We provided a link to compatible geotargeting plugins: https://wpml.org/plugin-functionality/geotargeting/ Regarding the structure of the websites (whether to build a multi-site or multiple individual sites), we noted that this decision depends on the client's business strategy and goes beyond what we can advise on as support.

text: The client is experiencing issues with managing sticky posts in different languages using WPML and another plugin to enable sticky post behavior for custom post types. Despite disabling 'Synchronize sticky flag' in WPML, the query still returns translations of sticky posts that are not selected as sticky in the current language.
solution:
We recommend filtering the sticky post IDs to include only those in the current language before running the query. Here is a step-by-step approach: $current_lang = apply_filters( 'wpml_current_language', null );
$stickies = array_filter(
get_option( 'sticky_posts', [] ),
fn( $id ) => apply_filters( 'wpml_post_language_details', null, $id )['language_code'] === $current_lang
);

$args = [
'post_type' => ['post', 'events'],
'post__in' => $stickies ?: [0],
'suppress_filters' => false,
];

$query = new WP_Query( $args );
This solution ensures that only sticky posts from the active language are queried, working regardless of fallback settings and without needing to change the post type translation mode.

text: The client is experiencing errors on both the front end and backend of their website when WPML plugins are active. Even after renaming the WPML plugins via FTP, the issues are not fully resolved, and the client is able to log in to the backend again. The client inquires if there is an issue with the most recent version of WPML and PHP 8.4.13.
solution: We resolved the problem by adjusting the 'Sidebar position' setting on the translated page. Originally, it was set to 'Right' on the translation, whereas it was 'Disabled' on the original page. We updated this setting using WPBakery Page Builder on the Dutch version of the page and ensured it was consistent with the original. Additionally, we enabled the 'Show ‘Multilingual Content Setup’ meta box on post edit screen' option in WPML → Settings → Custom Fields Translation. This setting helps display the custom fields on the page. We also set the relevant custom fields to 'Copy' to ensure that settings like Sidebar Position will automatically sync to translated pages in future translations.

text: The client was experiencing issues with their WPML editor where translations were not displaying correctly. They expected to see a column with original language texts and another with translations, but instead, some items showed translations while most displayed the original text. The client had previously set up a staging site and migrated the translation memory, which was treated as a separate entity, causing the main site to lose its translations.
solution: We advised the client that during the staging site setup, they should have selected the option 'I logged in from another domain' to ensure the staging site was connected to the same automatic translation account as the live site. This would have allowed the sites to share the translation memory and avoid re-translating content that was already translated. We provided documentation on how to properly connect websites and share their translation memory: https://wpml.org/documentation/automatic-translation/automatic-translation-subscription-for-multiple-sites/ . If the client confirms, we can also manually copy the memory back to the live site from our side.
